articles.headline: New York Courts Vow Legal Aid in Housing
articles.snippet: A foreclosure defendant without a lawyer will be supplied with one by volunteer groups.
articles.abstract: A foreclosure defendant without a lawyer will be supplied with one by volunteer groups.
articles.lead_paragraph: New York court officials outlined procedures Tuesday aimed at assuring that all homeowners facing foreclosure were represented by a lawyer, a shift that could give tens of thousands of families a better chance at saving their homes.

articles.headline: Egypt Leaders Found ‘Off’ Switch for Internet
articles.snippet: A blackout during protests has mesmerized technical experts and raised concerns about other governments.
articles.abstract: A blackout during protests has mesmerized technical experts and raised concerns about other governments.
articles.lead_paragraph: Epitaphs for the Mubarak government all note that the mobilizing power of the Internet was one of the Egyptian opposition’s most potent weapons. But quickly lost in the swirl of revolution was the government’s ferocious counterattack, a dark achievement that many had thought impossible in the age of global connectedness. In a span of minutes just after midnight on Jan. 28, a technologically advanced, densely wired country with more than 20 million people online was essentially severed from the global Internet.
articles.byline: By James Glanz and John Markoff

articles.headline: For Egypt, a Fresh Start, With Cities
articles.snippet: The only large country to have become less urban in the last 30 years may have missed a chance for growth.
articles.abstract: The only large country to have become less urban in the last 30 years may have missed a chance for growth.
articles.lead_paragraph: It would be easy to look at the images coming out of Cairo over the last few weeks and think of Egypt as a highly urbanized society. It would also be wrong.

articles.headline: No Dice, No Money, No Cheating. Are You Sure This Is Monopoly?
articles.snippet: The new version of Monopoly replaces many of the game’s old-fashioned elements with a computer that runs the game.
articles.abstract: The new version of Monopoly replaces many of the game’s old-fashioned elements with a computer that runs the game.
articles.lead_paragraph: You can still collect $200 when you pass “Go,” but not in piles of play money.

articles.headline: Legal Fees at Fannie Are Called Avoidable
articles.snippet: When the government took over Fannie Mae, it could have voided the contracts that have since left taxpayers liable for more than $100 million in legal bills, according to a legal opinion.
articles.abstract: When the government took over Fannie Mae, it could have voided the contracts that have since left taxpayers liable for more than $100 million in legal bills, according to a legal opinion.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  When the government took over Fannie Mae, it could have voided the contracts that have since left taxpayers liable for more than $100 million in legal bills defending the mortgage company and its former executives, according to statements at a Congressional hearing on Tuesday.

articles.headline: From Prison, Madoff Says Banks ‘Had to Know’ of Fraud
articles.snippet: In his first interview for publication since his arrest, Bernard L. Madoff insisted that his family knew nothing about his crimes, but some banks and hedge funds “had to know.”
articles.abstract: In his first interview for publication since his arrest, Bernard L. Madoff insisted that his family knew nothing about his crimes, but some banks and hedge funds “had to know.”
articles.lead_paragraph: BUTNER, N.C. — Bernard L. Madoff said he never thought the collapse of his Ponzi scheme would cause the sort of destruction that has befallen his family.

articles.headline: Obama, Conceding Budget’s Limitations, Seeks Consensus
articles.snippet: President Obama said that any compromise to address Medicare, Medicaid and Social Security would first require an effort to build bipartisan trust.
articles.abstract: President Obama said that any compromise to address Medicare, Medicaid and Social Security would first require an effort to build bipartisan trust.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama conceded on Tuesday that his new budget does not do enough to resolve the nation’s long-term fiscal problems, but he counseled patience, suggesting that he would eventually come together with Republicans on a broad deal.

articles.headline: Phones Try to Stand Out in a Crowd
articles.snippet: Manufacturers are designing phones on the Android platform with options like 3-D, sophisticated gaming controls or push-button access to Facebook.
articles.abstract: Manufacturers are designing phones on the Android platform with options like 3-D, sophisticated gaming controls or push-button access to Facebook.
articles.lead_paragraph: BARCELONA, Spain  It is the modern phone maker’s quandary. In the touch-screen era, how do you stand out from the crowd when most phones are near-identical glassy rectangles?

articles.headline: Angry Demonstrations in Wisconsin as Cuts Loom
articles.snippet: Thousands of protesters went to the governor’s office to protest some of the biggest cutback plans in the nation.
articles.abstract: Thousands of protesters went to the governor’s office to protest some of the biggest cutback plans in the nation.
articles.lead_paragraph: MADISON, Wis.  As four game wardens awkwardly stood guard, protesters, scores deep, crushed into a corridor leading to the governor’s office here on Wednesday, their screams echoing through the Capitol: “Come out, come out, wherever you are!”
articles.byline: By Monica Davey and Steven Greenhouse
